Hi Petar,

I'm the guy Carolina mentioned as a friend on her message. We're aware
of NEAT's FAQ and some old topics on that matter. But basically our
point is that if we keep innovation numbers for the entire simulation
we don't really need them!

While crossing over or measuring genotypes distance all it takes to
work is aligning connections that links the same neurons. It is the
very same effect when using "universal" innovation numbers, isn't it?

Two or more mutations that results in the same connection genes
during evolution plays the same role? Maybe not. I don't know.

Cesar

On 10/3/07, petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Hi Carolina,
>
>  Basically you can either keep the list of innovation numbers for the
>  current generation only or keep it forever. Try to experiment with
>  each and then see what is best for your system.
>
>  Perhaps searching for some older threads where the same issue is
>  discussed will help you.
>
>  Peter
>
>  --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Carolina Feher da Silva"
>
>  <mirrorballu2@...> wrote:
>  >
>  > It's been just a few months since I've started studying NEAT and I'm
>  > sorry if my question is very basic or has already been asked a lot
>  of
>  > times before (I've searched the group archive). I've been discussing
>  > this with my friend and we don't understand how innovation numbers
>  are
>  > assigned to mutations.
>  >
>  > Suppose a mutation links node n to node m. If another mutation
>  linking
>  > these nodes occurs in the same generation, they are both assigned
>  the
>  > same innovation number, this part was clear. But what if a mutation
>  > linking the same nodes occurs 100 generations later? Is it assigned
>  > the same innovation number or a different one?
>  >
>  > I've read Stanley's original C++ code and it seems that the new
>  > mutation is assigned a new innovation number, which makes sense to
>  me,
>  > because the two genes are not homologous and tracking homology among
>  > genes is the whole point of innovation numbers, right? But looking
>  at
>  > a Python and a Java implementation, both have a global list of
>  > mutations and will assign the same innovation number to a mutation
>  > linking the same nodes. In this case, don't innovation numbers
>  become
>  > useless? All we need to know to align genes for reproduction is
>  which
>  > nodes are getting linked by a certain mutation. Also we could be
>  > aligning genes that have completely different roles in completely
>  > different network architectures. It seems wrong to me.
>  >
>  > So does anyone know how this should be done and why?
>  >
>  > Thanks,
>  > Carolina
>  >
>
>
>
>
